ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was very useful for getting acquainted with the members of our department and for gaining professionalization tips. I always looked forward to attending. I hope that this continues for next year's first-year cohort, as it also gave me an opportunity to get to know my cohort-mates. It gave me an opportunity to learn more about the academic/personal backgrounds of many professors, many of whom I do not encounter on a frequent basis. It showed me how welcoming and supportive the sociology department is.
I got to know all of the faculty members and how they became sociologists. There were chances to get a glimpse of their personality, advising style and their values as a researcher.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great introduction session for professors and 1st-year students. However, I think the time is too limited to talk more in-depth.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I hope this seminar is open to non-1st year PhD students, who did not get the chance to meet new professors or professors on-leave. This class is a great way to get to know each other and to further develop the relationships between professors and students.
